Error Handling

Proper mechanisms to handle errors are an integral part of modern program languages. Being a modern language, Emojicode provides a sophisticated but light-weight way to handle errors.

The ğŸš¨ Type

Emojicode provides a special type: ğŸš¨. A ğŸš¨ type is always composed pf two other types: An enumeration that serves as the error enumeration, which indicates the kind of error if an error occurs, and a contained type, i.e. the type that is present if no error arises.

For instance, a method that normally returns a ğŸ”¡ can declare that it will return an instance of ğŸœ in case of an error like this:

ğŸ– ğŸ™… â¡ï¸ ğŸš¨ğŸœğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡

An instance of a ğŸš¨ type therefore either contains an error in the form of an enumeration value or a value of the contained type.

The ğŸš¨ Statement

An error can only ever be created and raised inside a function. In a function the ğŸš¨ statement, which works similar to ğŸ, is used to create the error and return it from the function. Its syntax is:

error âŸ¶ ğŸš¨ expression

The expression must evaluate to an instance of the error enumeration. The example below shows a class, which stands for a microphone. It hash a method called ğŸ¬ that in some cases might fail, in which an error is returned:

  ğŸ”˜ğŸŒŠ

Error Initializer

Since initializers can fail too, Emojicode also allows initializers to return errors. The error enumeration is declared after the ğŸˆ like this:

ğŸˆ ğŸš¨â›° ğŸ¦€ frequency ğŸš€ ğŸ‡

A contained value must not be provided, as the contained value is obviosuly the type instantiated.

ğŸ¥‘ Error Check Control

Emojicode provides a control flow mechanism that is specifically designed for error checking:

error-check-control âŸ¶ ğŸ¥‘ variable expression block ğŸ“ variable block

The ğŸ¥‘ works in a straight-forward way. If the expression evaluates to an ğŸš¨ instance that does not represent an error, the first block is executed an the variable is set to the value contained in the ğŸš¨. If, however, the ğŸš¨ does represent an error the ğŸ“ block is entered its variable is set to the error enumeration instance.

Example:

ğŸ¥‘ fileData ğŸ©ğŸ“‡ğŸ“„ ğŸ”¤textDocument.txtğŸ”¤ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸªğŸ”¤Read ğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¡ ğŸ” fileData 10 ğŸ”¤ bytesğŸ”¤ ğŸª
ğŸ‰
ğŸ“ error ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¤ğŸ˜¢ Could not read fileğŸ”¤
ğŸ‰

ğŸš¥ Test for Errors

To test whether an ğŸš¨ instance represents an error the ğŸš¥ expression is used.

Syntax:

is-error âŸ¶ ğŸš¥ expression

ğŸš¥ returns ğŸ‘ if the value is an error or ğŸ‘ false if its not an error and contains a value.

ğŸš‡ Perfect Extraction

If you are sure that an ğŸš¨ instance will never represent an error you can use the ğŸš‡ expression to the take contained value without prior error checking.

Syntax:

perfect-extraction âŸ¶ ğŸš‡ expression

If, though, the ğŸš¨ instance represents an error at runtime the program will abort with a run-time error similar to:

ğŸš¨ Fatal Error: Unexpectedly found ğŸš¨ with value 2.

Compatibility of the ğŸš¨ Type

ğŸš¨ types are intentionally not compatible to other types to enforce prompt error handling. ğŸš¨ types are only compatible to other types with the exact same error enumeration and contained type.
